column3: et abominábiles facti sunt in stúdiîs suîs~; non est qụi fáçiat bonum
column4: non est usqụe ad unum. ^ The fool hath said in his heart
column5: "There is no God". They are corrupt
column6: and are become abominable in their pursuits~; there is none that doth good

column1: 2 ^ Dòminus de caĕlo prospèxit super fílios hòminum
column3: aŭt reqụírens Deum. ^ The Lord hath looked down from heaven upon the children of men
column4: to see if there be any that understand and seek God.

column2: sìmul inútiles facti sunt. Non est qụi fáçiat bonum
column3: non est usqụe ad unum. ^ They are all gone aside
column4: they are become unprofitable together. There is none that doth good

column2: qụi dévorant plebem meam sicut escam panis~? ^ Shall not all they know that work iniquity
column3: who devour my people as the food of bread~?

column1: 5 ^ Dòminum non invocavérunt~; illic trepidavérunt timóre
column2: ubi non èrat tìmor. ^ They have not called upon the Lord~; there have they trembled for fear

column1: 6 ^ Qụóniam Dòminus in ģenerațióne justa est~; consìlium ìnopis confudìstis
column2: qụóniam Dòminus spes ejus est. ^ For the Lord is in the just generation~; you have confounded the counsel of the poor man
column3: but the Lord is his hope.

column1: 7 ^ ¿~Qụìs dabit ex Sióne salutáre Israhélis~? Qụum avèrterit Dòminus captivitátem plebis suaĕ
column3: et laĕtábitur Isráhel. ^ Who shall give out of Sion the salvation of Israel~? When the Lord shall have turned away the captivity of his people
